AUFGEBOT.

Es wird hiermit bekannt gemacht, dass der badische Staatsangehörige Emil Lauer, seines Standes Kaufmann, geboren in Freiburg (Baden), 33 Jahre alt, wohnhaft in Alexandrien, Sohn des im Alter von 54 Jabren in Freiburg ver- storbenen und dort zuletzt wohnhaft gewesenen Lehrers Christian Lauer und dessen Ehefrau der in Freiburg wohnhaften 53 Jahre alten Elise Lauer geborenen Schrodin, ohne Beruf, und die württembergische Staatsangehörige Henriette Keller, geboren in Haifa (Syrien), 26 Jahre alt, wohnhaft in Haifa, Tochter des in Haifa wohnhaften 67 Jahre alten Landwirts und Kaiserlichen Honorar-Vizekonsuls Friedrich Keller und dessen Ehefrau der in Haifa wohn- haften 62 Jahre alten Katharina Keller gebo renen Krafft, ohne Beruf, beabsichtigen, sich mith einander zu verheiraten, und diese Ehe in Gemässheit des Gesetzes vom 4. Mai 1870 vor dem Kaiserlichen Vizekonsul in Haifa abzuschliessen.
Alexandrien, den 10. Mai 1905.
Der Kaiserliche Konsul von HUMBOLDT.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: INGLIS.- On the 3rd May, at Moorfiel 1, Wit ington, Manches ter, to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Inglis, of Tantah, a daughter.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, MAY 11, 1905..

div.head: ANTHROPOMETRY AND CRIME.
div.p:
For many years past Lord Cromer, in his annual Reports, has directed attention to the Anthropometric Bureau which was established in Egypt in 1896. The steady progress made in this direction is evidenced by the fact that while in 1897, the year after the system was established, the number of identifications by means of finger-prints was only 177, in 1904 it had reached 1,405, the old practice of measuring criminals having been quite superseded by the later and more effective plan of taking impressions of the shape and markings of the fingers. It is however some- what disappointing to be told, in spite of the many proofs given of the value of the new system, that, in the words of Colonel Harvey in his latest report on the subject, "some few judges refuse to allow any attempt to be made before them in court in identifica tion by finger-prints." On this Lord Cromer remarks: "It is indeed astonishing that some Egyptian judges are still reluctant to avail themselves of the services of the Anthro- pometric Bureau. The identification system is singular'y adapted for application in Egypt. It is greatly to be hoped that, as it becomes more thoroughly understood, any hesita- tion to employ it will pass away." One great advantage of its practice is that although mainly useful in establishing the antece- dents of habitual criminals, it has been the means on several occasions of preventing gross miscarriages of justice. Of these one instance is given in the Report, where a man about to be sentenced at Damanhour protested energe
Sunlight
There is no rubbing and
scrubbing with
Sunlight Soap.
One bar of it, when used according to directions, will do more than two bars of common soap.
Soap
tically against 27 ot the previous convictions attributed to him. The case was adjourned for expert evidence, which, when given, proved conclusively that the 27 antecedents belonged to a prisoner at Alexandria. The judge him- self investigated the case, and on proceeding to Alexandria satisfied himself that this was so, and was convinced of the value of the system, as to which he had previously been sceptical. A case is under investigation in England which, in all probability, will cause renewed interest in this question of finger-markings. We must make very guarded reference to this, as we have no right, even at this distance from home, to write a word that would tend to prejudice a matter that is sub-judice, and involves the lives of two men, but we can with perfect freedom mention a piece of evidence given, before the magistrates on oath, by the inspector of the Finger Print Depart ment at New Scotland Yard. This official stated that in the department, to which he had been attached since it was originated, the police possessed 90,000 sets of finger- prints. He had had ten years' experience in comparing finger, prints, and the highest num- ber of points of identity found to agree in finger prints of two individuals was three. When there were four or more the finger-print was from the same person. In answer to questions from counsel the inspector stated that the system had been in force since 1895, and was called a science, adding that he was not aware that in learned circles there was any controversy as to the correctness of the theory, or that it was said by some to be a danger to the public. It acted in two ways, for it fre quently enabled a man to establish his in- nocence of charges, and to correct errors made in personal recognition, while it helped to strengthen the cases against the guilty. He had not yet found any case in which a mistake had been made through relying on finger- prints. This testimony should help to trengthen the case for a more complete adop tion of the system in Egypt, where it is noto- rious that evidence on oath can be little relied ou, and where, therefore, a perfectly reliable method of identification is all the more valuable.

While any new system that can in any way increase efficiency and accuracy in criminal procedure should be heartily welcomed, a far larger question lies in the background, and should be kept in view by all reformers, viz., that of the treatment of criminals. More and more is it becoming recognised that criminality is in the nature of a disease, and simply the exercise of natural abilities and gifts in a wrong direction; that our present treatment of criminals is calculated to harden their na- tares and to make them worse rather than better; and that if we want to turn the offender into a respectable member of society, we must alter our system of treatment root and branch, and, abandoning the old lines of "vindicating the law," proceed on a more reasonable and enlightened policy than that of "an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth." The fact that finger- prints can be made to establish a man's identity has been amply demonstrated, and it is but another proof that the more we study our fellow man, the more we shall find out about him and the distinctive features that reveal themselves the closer our observa- tion goes. Supposing instead of one uniform system of treatment in accordance with the class of offence committed, our prisoners, espe cially the younger ones, were examined phrenologically, and that their capacities were estimated (even if not exactly ascertained) by means of the many physiological and psycho- logical sciences of the present day, and that a system of treatment suited to their several characters was adopted, which would give them a chance of taking the place in the community for which these examinations showed them to be fitted, would not a great step have been taken for the lasting benefit of humanity, one that must inevitably result in good from the very first If we are told that the idea is Utopian, we reply that it is our aim not merely to keep abreast of the times, but to be in advance of them. The very subject upon which we have been writing (finger-marks) was dealt with in fiction long before the idea took prac- tical shape, for we remember reading a short, tale, published probably twenty or twenty-five years ago, in which the leading incident was the detection of a murder and robbery by means of a thumb mark made by the perpe- trator, one of a large body of workmen, of whose thumbs impressions were taken. And as the fiction of yesterday is the fact of to-day,
and the dream of to-day is the reality of to-morrow, so it is not by any means idle to anticipate the reforms of the future, and to indicate the directions in which we think they may be accomplished,

div.head: THE RUSSIAN FLEET. JUNCTION OF THE SQUADRONS

div.p: Admiral Rodjestvensky, who has been cruis ing off Vamfong Bay for several days, left to day with the whole fleet. (Reuter.)

Two cruisers of Rodjestvensky's squadron came to Cape Saint Jacques and brought instructions for Admiral Nobogatoff. The latter took to the high seas again and effected his junction with Admiral Rodjestvensky. (R.)
Admirals Nebogatoff and Rodjestvensky have effected a junction in neutral waters. (R.)
The Russians are preparing to move their base hospital from Harnin to Transbaikalia, anticipating the necessity of evacuating Harbin in the near future. (Reuter.)
The Circum-Baikal railway is blocked owing to an avalanche. (Reuter.)

The congress of Zemstvos is closed. It adopted a programme providing for the crea- tion of two assemblies, the first chosen by universal suffrage, the second consisting of delegates from autonomous institutions. (R.)
A leading French resident, M. Bougouin, his step son, and an unknown Englishman have been arrested here. They are charged with being spies. (Reuter.)
Count Cassini, Russian Ambassador here, has been transferred to Madrid. Baron do Rosen, formerly at Tokio, will succeed him. (Reuter.)

div.head: ITALY IN THE MEDITERRANEAN. HER INTERESTS IN TRIPOLI.

div.p: Signor Tittoni, speaking in the Senate, said that the Navy Bill will be submitted to that Parliament with the object of safeguarding Italian interests in the Mediterranean. He denied that Italy intended to occupy Tripoli but said that Italy had an economic preference there, and was entitled to take the steps neces sary for the industrial and economic develop ment of the country. He could not tolerate the distrust shown by the Turkish officials. (R.)

div.head: EARTHQUAKE AT BANDAR ABBAS INHABITANTS PANIC STRICKEN.

div.p: An earthquake at Bandar Abbas on the 25t April caused a mountain behind the town t partly collapse, burying fifty persons. Severn houses fell and there have been shocks ever day since. The inhabitants are panic-stricken (Reuter.)
The Porte intends to send a mission to Fez (Havas.)
Chester Cup. 1, Imari; 2, Mark Time ; Throwaway. 10 ran. Betting: 100 to 8 against Imari; 4 to 1 against Mark Time; 6 to 1 again Throwaway. Won by three-quarters of length. 2nd and 3rd same. (Reuter)

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: The Fayoum Brigands
div.p: Abbass Ezoomor, the leader of the Fayomn brigands, has been arrested.
Quarantine restrictions as against plague are now applied to arrivals in Egyptian ports from Porbandar.

div.head: General Holiday
div.p: All the Ministries, Government offices, and banks will be closed on Saturday next

div.head: The Cotton Worm
div.p: The Ministry, of the Interior has ceased granting leave of absence to the Moudirs owing to the prevalence of cotton worm.

div.head: Public Works Department
div.p: During the absence on leave of Mohamed Anis Pasho, Mr. Crawley, director of works, will act as head of the technical department.
The Gordon Memorial College at Khartoum has been bequeathed £500 by the will of the late Mr. Horace Downey Harrel, of Chobham Cottage, Chobham, who died on January 3.

div.head: Killed, by his Father
div.p: A report has been received from Boni Souef stating that Said Ibrahim, a native of Berber Murkaz, has killed his son with tho blow of an axe. On arrest the man pleaded guilty.

div.head: Land and General Trust
div.p: Application has been made to the Stock Exchange Com- mittee to appoint a special settling day in and to grant a quotation to : Egyptian Land and General Trust, 200,000 shares of £1 each, 5s. paid.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On the 8th inst 12 vessels passed through the Canal, 8 of which were British, 1 French, 1 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Aus- trian. The day's receipts were frs. 251,231.84, making the total from the 1st 'inst. frs. 2,62!, 910.84.

div.head: State Domains
div.p: Messrs. N. M. Rothschild and Sons announce that a drawing of Egyptian State Domain mortgage bonds, amounting to 185,220 nominal capital, will take place this month. The bonds so drawn will cease to bear interest from June 1.

div.head: Egyptian Relics
div.p: General Lord Greufell, who is this year president of the Royal Insti- tution of South Wales, at Swansea, has just forwarded some additional Egyptian relics to the museum of the institution. Among those already given by Lord Grenfell is a mummy.

div.head: Corporation or Western Egypt, Ltd
div.p: Mr. Edward J. Scott, late District Commissioner and Political Officer in Nigeria, has been appointed Secretary to the Egyptian Board of the Corporation in Egypt. Mr. Scott has arrived in Cairo, and has entered upon his duties.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: By general request, Primavera Scapigliata will be repeated at tho Alhambra this evening. To-morrow, the first performance will be given of I Viaggi di Satur- nino Faradola. On Saturday, on the occasion Ot tho Mohamed Aly centenary, a gala performance will be given, and the theatre will be illuminated.

div.head: Pharmacy Closed
div.p: The Sanitary Depart- ment has ordered tho cloring of the Mousky pharmacy and drug-stores,in Sharia el Chaouaz- iia, belonging to Messrs. Zilbermann&Co., for an infringement of the new pharmacy regulations,the proprietor not being a qualified chemist himself and not having a qualified man as manager.

div.head: Cairo and Alexandria Cold Storage Com- pany, Limited.
div.p: Registered April 29. Capital, £7 in £1 shares. Object, to carry on in Egypt or elsewhere the business of proprietors of coldair stores and receiving depots for meat and other produce, &c. No initial public issue. Registered without articles of association.

div.head: An Island in the Nile
div.p: A London finan- cial contemporary states that an island in the Nile was offered in London a few months ago for £6,000. It was subsequently sold at public auction for £120,000. Negotiations are now pending for it to change bands agai. this time on the basis of £1,000,000. After that, J who will say there is no corn in Egypt

div.head: P.W.D. Contracts.
div.p: The Public Works Department has given the contract for building the road bridges over the Ibrabimieh Canal, between the Guenidi regulator and Zeitoun (Projects Circle) to M. C. Gandolfi; for the Esbet Cherif Pasha and Mangoriche bridges to z. M. L. Santrapfrze ; for the Bouche and Zeitonn bridges and the supply of 700 tons of ooal for the Ghizeh pumping service to M. Soussa.

div.head: A Hero of El Teb
div.p: Major W. T. Marshall, V.C., 19th Hussars, has been selected to fill the appointment of Camp Quarter-master, Aldershot Army Corps, in succession to Major J. Poole, 10th Hussars, who is shortly vacating the post. Major Marshall, as a non-commissioned officer, won his V.C. at the battle of El Teb, during the Sudan expedition of 1884. Ho took part in the cavalry charge, during which Lieut- Colonel Borrow was severely wounded, and his horse killed. The colonel was on the ground surrounded by the enemy, when Quartermaster sergeant Marshall, who stayed behind with him, seized his band and dragged him through the enemy back to the regiment.

div.head: THE PIGMIES AT CAIRO DATE OF DEPARTURE.
div.p: Col. Harrison's pigmies will leave Cairo direct for London in via Port Said on the 18th inst. They are exceedingly well in health and have gained considerably in weight. It is worthy of note that when Stanley first carme upon the pigmies he was struck in quite an unwonted way. The first of them that he beheld was a captive, some four feet high, "but more venerable than the Memnonium of Thebes." Here was the oldest type of primeval man. Forty centuries ago, the famous battle between these pigmies and the storks was put into song. Think of it ' he is fain to ejaculate.

"Oil every map since Hekataeus' time 500 years before Christ, they have been located in the Mountains of tho Moon, and there they are yet, while all the dynasties of Egypt, and Syria, and Persia, and Rome have flourished, and expired." Well, yes. And if these little people, who run from three feet to four feet six inches, and whose average weight is 9O lb., and whose most marked talent, at any rate in Stanley's time, was tho poisoning of arrows, represent a survival of the fittest, the, Darwinian theory gets a knock.

div.head: RETURN OF THE MAHMAL.
div.p: The escort of the Mahmal, viz., cavalry, infantry, and artillery, showed signs of great fatigue. The horses especially were completely exhausted.

It appears that they all suffered considerably this year, and tho fighting with the- Bedouins was serious. However, tho latter were repulsed with heavy losses, while the escort of dthe Mahmal lost one officer and four men killed, and about 22 wounded.
The special train convoying the Holy Carpet to Cairo left Suez at 1 o'clock this morning.

div.head: THE MECCA RAILWAY.
div.p: The "Kiiluische Zoitung," of Berlin, learns from Constantinople that an interruption has occurred in the execution of tho great under- taking which is intended to connect by rail the Mohauiodan places of pilgrimage with the Mediterranean. The extension of the projocted railway bejond Maau, an Arabian town- 84 miles south coast of Jerusalem, is being carried out only very slowly, while the important section of the line between Demand Haifa, which is the real line of exit leading to the Mediterranean, has suffered severely from inundations, and cannot be built as it was intended; while, lastly, tho plan of laying down a branch line to Akaba, on the Red Sea, has been giving up, greatly to the keen regret of a number of young and serious officers in tho Turkish Army. The disorders in Yemon havo shown clearly the great value of. such a linc/of railway leading southwards from Damascus\to the Rod Sea, for it would facilitate the trans- port of troops of the Syrian Army Corps into Arabia, and there would not be the dreary march across the desert.

div.head: THE MARIOUT DISTURBANCES.
div.p: We have received tho following official statement as to. the recent disturbances at Mariout on Sunday last.

The Ministry of Finance despatched last week a sarraf, Ghirghis Effendi by name, to Mariout in order to draw up a report ou the ownership of some laud and crops in the Amrieh district. On Sunday last tho sarraf was in that neighbourhood when he saw a number of fellaheen attesting to get to some land belonging to Bedouins. The latter barred their way and told them that if they persisted they would fight The fellaheen replied that the laud belonged to them, and a discussion ensued which led to blows.
The sarraf was merely a witness of the fight and was not hurt at all. The omdeh and sheikh and one mounted police man were with the sarraf, and this escort was sufficient to protect that official.

The policeman belonging to the escort, on witnessing the disturbance, redo off to the markaz to inform tho mamour, who at once saddled and bridled and galloped off to the scene of the trouble. Ho arrived on the spot scarcely an hour after the beginning of the engagement. When he arrived on the scene of action he found three fellaheen slightly wounded with bows from nabouts. About 12 of the combatants were then arrested and charged with riotous conduct. They have been sent to Alexandria for trial.

There are now 30 police officers and men in the Mariout district Eighteen months age there was a total of only seven police officers and men there. Patrols are mode daily, and the Bedouins are gradually getting to reaped law and order.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: The six British torpedo-destroyers "Dee," "Erne," "Ettrick," "Arun," "Exe,"and "Itchen sailed from Suez yesterday afternoon bound t Singapore.

div.head: BECK & CO'S PILSENER BEER
div.p: BREMEN.
FEARS NO HONEST COMPETITION FOR QUALITY.
N.B. -- Inferior Brands now being offered to Managers of certain good circles.
Beware of evilly disposed competitors running down this very Superior Brand of Beer
xxxxx-xx-x xx

div.head: MOHAMED ALY CENTENARY. CELEBRATIONS AT CAIRO.
div.p: The following is- the general programme of die festivities to be held on Saturday next at Cairo : 7.30 p.m., procession of school children through Mohamed Aly-square, Ataba el Kha- dra, Post Office-street, Abdeen-square. 8.30 p.m., night fete on the Nile ; illumination of die east quay, Kasr el-Nil Bridge, and the small promenade; illumination of boats anchored on both banks ; military and native bands; longs by Sheikh Salama, etc.

The Khedive has sent a letter to Chawarbi Pasha, president of tho Cairo committee, ex- pressing his regret at not being able to wit- ness tho fetes in Cairo on Saturday. His High- ness desires the president to convey to the members of the committee and all the subscri- bers, the satisfaction and pleasure be has in Acknowledging the spontaneous manifestation of sympathy with himself and the Khedivial family.

div.head: AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The following police measures for regulating traffic have been, ordered, for the occasion of the illuminations celebrating the centenary of Mohamed: Aly Pasha on .the 13th inst. All empty carriages and other vehicles will be forbidden to enter Mohamed Aly-square. The following streets only will be open for entrance thereto and exit therefrom for wheeled traffic.
ENTRANCE EXIT.
Cherif Pasha-street Tewfik Pasha-street Frauk-street Anastassi-street Sister-street Gama El-Sheikh-street
All other streets will be blocked except for foot passengers.
The open space in the centre of the square, on both sides of the statue, is likewise blocked for carriages.

Carriages will only be allowed to circulate in the square at a slow pace and in single file, commencing from the entrance of Cherif Pasha- street down to the Cafe d'Europe and from thence in the direction of Tewfik Pasha-street It is expected that the cafe at Alexandria Bourse will be Crowded on the night of the fete. On this occasion a charge of F.T. 5 per head, which will include a seat and refresh- ment will be made. It is understood that the proceeds will be divided among various local charities.
On the occasion of the Mohamed Aly cen- tenary, prayers will be said in tho different mosques, and alms will be distributed to the poor.

div.head: THE MADHOUSE MEMORIAL.
div.p: The scheme for erecting a madhouse to the memory of Mohamed Aly is meeting with some criticism. In the first place, the idea of a madhouse as a memorial is some- what bizarre, and it may well be doubted whether this project, however useful it may be, is suited to the dignity of the occasion. Moreover, in view of the fact that the Government intend building a large lunatic asylum in Lower Egypt between Alexandria and Tantah, as is announced in Lord Cromer's last Report, subscribers are hesitating, as they ask themselves what is tho utility of giving donations towards building an asylum when the Government has already decided to build one. Supporters of the scheme may reply that the madhouse which is to be built by the Government will not be actually situated in Alexandria itself. But as this asylum is to be built on the "Villa Colony" pattern, it is far bettor to construct it in a rural district. We may quote the actual words of Lord Cromer on tho subject :—

"I am glad to be able to report that there seems at last to be a fair prospect of providing adequate accommodation for lunatics in this country. In the first place, LE. 21,000 is to be spent during tho current year and in 1906, on inclosing 75 acres of desert land adjoining the present asylum, and on adapting and enlarging an existing building, now used as an army hospital for the use of lunatics. Thus the number of bods will be increased from 500 te 820. In the second place, the construction ol another large lunatic asylum is under conside- ration. Plans are being prepared, but the site has not yet been chosen. It will probably be situated somewhere between Tantah and Alexandra. The type of the new asylum will be that known as the "Villa Colony." Ian informed that this system has been tried with great success in Germany, and that it is eminently suited to the Egyptian climate."

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman SS. "Anatolia" arrived ai Liverpool on Wednesday morning.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Portugal,1 from Alexandria, arrived at Marseilles at 5 a.m yesterday.
The Canard S.S. "Pavia" will arrive hero of Saturday from Volo, and will immediately commence loading cargo for Liverpool am American porta.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: ( From Our Correspondant ).

div.head: MORE RUSSIAN REFUGEES.
div.p: To-day at 8 a.m., the Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Tonkin" arrived from Yokokama, having on board 24 Russian sailors, 4 military officers, and 84 refugees. The ship is to sail this after- noon for Marseilles direct.

I learn on good authority that those amongst the number who are wounded are to go to a sanatorium which has been specially prepared for them at Nice. The building, which from all accounts is magnificently situated, is rented by the Russian Government, and has a large medical and surgical staff, principally of French nationality.

div.head: P. & O. PASSENGERS.
div.p: For some time past the Suez Canal Company have employed a large number (some 800) of Arabs on the now dockyard and workshops which are in coarse of construc- tion so the Asian shore of the harbour. Arab town being on the west shore, these work- men are brought over by boat every evening about 6 o'clock I frequently see this horde of somewhat unruly characters, in bands of 50 to 100, land at tho main passenger jetty. Last evening they landed at the Custom House as usual and went up the main street (Rue de Commerce) shouting and laughing, much to the alarm of many lady passengers who had come ashore from the P. &0. "Mongolia," and who, fearing some sort of riot, took refuge in shops and hotels. -Seeing that coal coolies are not on any pretext allowed to traverse main thoroughfares, it is generally thought that the police might well include these frequently equally dirty crowds in the regulations, and so avoid such scenes. The name of Port Said is none so good, though much improved, that this state of things can be allowed to continue.

div.head: CONFLICT OF JURISDICTIONS. STRANGE CASE.
div.p: The Appeal Court of the Mixed Tribunals gave judgment in the case of Stagni v. Selinas on the 3rd inst, and as our readers are aware, the text of this judgment appeared in full in our columns a few days ago. Mr. Salinm, the well-known Alexandria stockbroker, won the case both in the Mixed Court of 1st Instance and in the Appeal Court But both Mr. Luigi Stagni and Mr. Salinas are Italian subjects, and the same case has also pi-.es before the Italian Consular Courts and to the Appeal Court at Ancona, where judgment was given in favor of Mr. Luigi Stagni. This gentleman has naturally decided to abide by the decision of the court which gave judgment in his favor, and two days ago levied an execution on the furniture of Mr. Salinas, although the latter is the successful suitor according to the Mixed Courts. Wo do not call to mind a more striking instance of the conflict of jurisdictions prevailing in Egypt.

div.head: A COTTON CORNER.
div.p: "A Native Landowner" (Helouan) writes:— Some merchants at Alexandria have arranged a "corner" in May cotton and have artificially raised the price by two dollars within the last three days. The price of May cotton is now 15 3/4 dollars, while last Saturday it was only 13 3/4 dollars. What is very strange is that while cotton is abundant in Alexandria, and there is one hundred thousand cantars more than last year at this time, still cotton at Alexandria is four dollars dearer than at Liverpool. Is not such a comer illegal and prohibited by the law? And will the Tribunals allow people to be robbed by such corners ?

div.head: PORT SAID SALT ASSOCIATION.
div.p: Owing to Saturday next being a Bank Holiday, the subscription list of the Egyptian Salt Association will close on Friday evening instead of Saturday.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Among the passengers for Constantinople by the S.S. "Prince Abbas," which left Alexandria yesterday, wore Princesses Said Pasah Halim, Abbas Pasha Halim, Judge Piggott, Count Etienne Zizinia, etc.
Lord and Lady Cromer are expected back from their excursion in Upper Egypt on the 17th inst.

Col. D. F. Lewis, C.B., A.D.C., who has been unemployed since he retired from the Egyptian Army in September, 1900, arrived at Port Said yesterday on his way from England to Manchuria, having been selected by the War Office to do duty with the Japanese army in the field as a Military Attache CoL Lewis will be remembered for the services he rendered under Lord Kitchener in the Sudan, especially in connexion with the pursuit and ultimate defeat and death of the Khalifa.
Captain Blomfield, of the Warwickshire Regiment, son of Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield, arrived at Port-Said by the P. &0. "Mongolia" on Tuesday. He has come to join the Egyptian Army.
Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield leave Alexandria for the Austrian Tyrol on the 27th inst.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHAKE KARKET. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDANT).
div.p: London May 5 Awaiting the events ! The very largeness of the impending struggle belittles all else. Mean time, rumors of peace negotiations are persist- ent but no one knows through what channel they come. Hope is perhaps "father to, the thought" that the Tsar may still have a grain of sense left, and may use the factor of doubt yet remaining to obtain some kind of terms. As yet there is no sign of activity in stock markets, and moreover, there is little induce- ment to lead to an increase of public business the position in the Far East being no clearer than it was a week ago, though the somewhat strained feeling in European diplomatic circles as reflected in financial circles seems to have almost passed away.

Japanese stocks have hardened a little, especially the new 4 1/2 per cent issue, the special settlement in which took place today, Consols are dull, and dealers in all quarters seem anxious to avoid having any position open, until the horizon is clearer.

Egyptian stocks are steady, but inactive. Daira Sanieh shares are a trifle lower at 285/8, ex a dividend of 3s.; and Bank shares are unchanged. In the mining section the tone is dull. The market at the moment is a neglected one, and suffers, in company with Booth Africans, from sheer want of business. Specu- latively—i.e. for any intermediate improvement -there is nothing tempting about this market, but, to take op and put away, prices are near, if they have not already reached, a cheap leveL

The wind was flesh from the N. The "Coot" was disqualified for knocking over the starting flag with her main boom. The prize in Class I. for the four races was won by the "Tier-el-Mina" and in Class II. by the "Laurea." Next week there will be a new handicap.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: E. T. C. v. KOM EL-DIK. The E.T.C. commenced a match on Tuesday against a 'Kom-el-Dik' XI. For the E.T.C., Messrs. Stacey and Cheesman put on 73 before being separated. The last wicket also pat on 48 runs. In bowling Mr. Henley took 8 wickets for 68. For 'Kom-el-Dik' Mr. Dawson played a good innings of 54. Scores E. T. C. Mr. Stacey, l.b.w., b. div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.
